review.title: Dynamic Capitalization and Visualization Strategy in Collaborative Knowledge Management System for EI Process
review.abstract: Knowledge is attributed to human whose problem-solving behavior is subjective and complex. In today's knowledge economy, the need to manage knowledge produced by a community of actors cannot be overemphasized. This is due to the fact that actors possess some level of tacit knowledge which is generally difficult to articulate. Problem-solving requires searching and sharing of knowledge among a group of actors in a particular context. Knowledge expressed within the context of a problem resolution must be capitalized for future reuse. In this paper, an approach that permits dynamic capitalization of relevant and reliable actors' knowledge in solving decision problem following Economic Intelligence process is proposed. Knowledge annotation method and temporal attributes are used for handling the complexity in the communication among actors and in contextualizing expressed knowledge. A prototype is built to demonstrate the functionalities of a collaborative Knowledge Management system based on this approach. It is tested with sample cases and the result showed that dynamic capitalization leads to knowledge validation hence increasing reliability of captured knowledge for reuse. The system can be adapted to various domains

sections.text: This is due to the fact that actors possess a certain level of tacit knowledge, which is usually difficult to articulate. Problem solving requires the search and exchange of knowledge between a group of actors in a particular context. Knowledge expressed in the context of problem solving must be used for future reuse. In this paper, an approach is used that allows a dynamic capitalization of relevant and reliable actors. Knowledge in solving decision problems following the process of economic intelligence is proposed. Knowledge annotation method and time attributes are used to deal with the complexity in communication between actors and knowledge expressed in the contextualization. A prototype is built to demonstrate the functionality of a collaborative knowledge management system based on this approach. It is tested with case studies and the result showed that dynamic capitalization can be adapted to different areas of the system.

sections.heading: II. REVIEW OF RELATED CONCEPTS AND APPLICATIONS
sections.text: It is a set of concepts, methods and tools that comprise all the coordinated actions of research, acquisition, treatment and dissemination of information relevant to the individual and of organisations that are part of a strategy. The aim of the campaign is to reduce uncertainty in the decision-making process, whether it is a process that relates to the following phases: decision-making problems, identification and definition of information necessary for the protection of information.

sections.heading: C. Collaborative Knowledge Management
sections.text: Knowledge Management (KM) is defined as a global process in an enterprise that encompasses all processes that enable the capitalization and sharing of the company's knowledge resources (capital). Knowledge cannot be decoupled from the context in which it is produced. Individuals or groups of individuals (knowledge producers) and their associated socio-cultural environment constitute the context of knowledge production. Therefore, KM considers the organizational culture in its implementation. It enables people with shared vision and culture to innovate through effective working. KM is therefore collaborative in nature. There are other factors that lie outside the culture that should be injected into the implementation of KM in organizations. These factors are organizational goals, technology and legal protection of Knowledge Resources (KR), [13], [14].

sections.heading: D. Review of existing KM systems
sections.text: KM is applicable to various disciplines such as industries, drugs, institutions and governments. Various KM systems have been developed in these disciplines, so we will discuss a few numbers of such applications.The capitalization of knowledge on how to synthesize "purely Swiss" vitamin C with emphasis on its impact on society through the influence of technology was discussed in [19], a system for capitalizing the design process, which focuses on the development of design project memories of designers [23] activities by directly extracting and tracking knowledge from project design tools, design processes and product data. Other applications include capitalization of business experience and resources [21], capitalization of steel production processes and deficits [22], capitalization of industrial systems, capitalization of device diagrams diagnosis and repair tools.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we explained a recursive dynamic capitalization or a KM approach to controlling actors. "Information expressed in problem-solving decision-making was problematized as a framework for strategic decision-making. Recursive dynamic algorithm for capitalizing knowledge was implemented in the form of a web-based prototype called the EICKC system. We conclude that the approach of dynamic capitalization of knowledge supports the process of knowledge validation among cooperating actors, thereby increasing the reliability of capital knowledge. Visualization of knowledge is advanced in the form of navigation systems under related KR or knowledge taxonomy. We are currently working on optimizing the visualization aspect of EICC systems for graphing knowledge networks. REFERENCE [1] V. Odumuyiwa, and S. Okunoye, A. David," Knowledge creation and enhancement element through collaborative information. "

metadata.abstractText: Knowledge is attributed to human whose problemsolving behavior is subjective and complex. In today‟s knowledge economy, the need to manage knowledge produced by a community of actors cannot be overemphasized. This is due to the fact that actors possess some level of tacit knowledge which is generally difficult to articulate. Problem-solving requires searching and sharing of knowledge among a group of actors in a particular context. Knowledge expressed within the context of a problem resolution must be capitalized for future reuse. In this paper, an approach that permits dynamic capitalization of relevant and reliable actors‟ knowledge in solving decision problem following Economic Intelligence process is proposed. Knowledge annotation method and temporal attributes are used for handling the complexity in the communication among actors and in contextualizing expressed knowledge. A prototype is built to demonstrate the functionalities of a collaborative Knowledge Management system based on this approach. It is tested with sample cases and the result showed that dynamic capitalization leads to knowledge validation hence increasing reliability of captured knowledge for reuse. The system can be adapted to various domains. Keywords— Actors‟ communication, knowledge annotation, recursive knowledge capitalization, visualization.
